awd_titl_txt: INFEWS/T3: Critical Nutrient Recovery and Reuse: Nitrogen and Phosphorus Recycling from Wastewaters as Struvite Fertilizer
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is supported by the Innovations at the Nexus of Food, Energy, and Water (INFEWS) Program. It addresses the lack of nutrient recycling from wastewater streams and the resulting strain on water resources, energy use, and sustainable food supply. Two key nutrients, nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P), are critical for all life on Earth, including humans, animals, and plants. Worldwide, phosphorus supply comes from limited stores of phosphate rock. Nitrogen comes from the energy- and capital-intensive industrial Haber-Bosch process that makes ammonia.  Phosphorus and nitrogen are transported from fertilizers and human and animal waste to wastewaters via agricultural run-off. There is an important opportunity for nutrient recovery and reuse rather than treatment and disposal. This project develops innovative engineering technology to recycle nitrogen and phosphorus nutrients as a high-value fertilizer, struvite, while also enabling energy-efficient wastewater treatment. The technology is developed within the context of an economic life cycle analysis. In terms of broadening participation, a stakeholder-driven workshop takes place yearly. In addition to lower energy use and increased nitrogen and phosphorus recycling, the benefits are cleaner water, healthier watersheds, and sustainable agricultural activities. Numerous undergraduate and graduate students receive training in an interdisciplinary context.

Over-fertilization and excess ammonia production in addition to a lack of nutrient recycling contribute to an imbalanced N/P cycle. This situation leads to water contamination issues, decreased agricultural viability in nutrient-saturated watersheds, and excessive energy use. This research project addresses the problem with an electrochemical reactor that recovers N and P as struvite, a slow-release fertilizer. An electrochemical reactor is designed to study kinetics and flow dynamics of struvite precipitation. This reactor is designed to be energy-efficient with high potential for on-site power generation. Key electrochemical components, including the magnesium alloy anode and a functional peptide scaffold for accelerated struvite precipitation are developed. The peptide-functionalized mesh is designed to enhance struvite precipitation kinetics and purity. The energy requirements for this process are evaluated and the economic costs and benefits of the new technology are determined. The project also addresses the impact of struvite composition and morphology on soil composition and crop fertility, studies the efficacy of struvite as a fertilizer, and develops a life cycle assessment of the technology including a system energy balance. For application to municipal wastewater treatment facilities, the technology integration is evaluated in terms of scalability, water quality/liquid composition, and cost-effectiveness.

por.por_cntn:
Major findings for this project, Critical Nutrient Recovery and Reuse: Nitrogen and Phosphorus Recycling from Wastewaters as Struvite Fertilizer, are summarized in five categories.

First, scientific knowledge has been enhanced by the control of magnesium electrode fouling through pulsed voltage control of the electrochemical system, which also enhances struvite recovery and reduces the energy consumption of the electrochemical precipitation process. Pulsed voltage control of electrode fouling and performance was demonstrated with a real wastewater sample, and results showed that this voltage control approach also increases struvite purity (i.e., decreases metal impurities). In addition, water chemistry has a direct effect on struvite recovery, where the concentration of chloride can have a beneficial effect on magnesium electrode corrosion. Other related outcomes include a demonstration of electrochemical struvite in a large-scale laboratory setup, along with demonstration of struvite formation from magnesium electrodes without electrical energy input. These project results show the range of potential application of electrochemical technology for wastewater treatment and fertilizer resource recovery. Project investigators also explored the role of engineered peptides in nutrient recovery. The intellectual merit of this work are the discoveries that a high throughput platform can identify useful peptide sequences for struvite recovery, that an amelogenin-derived peptide can increase yield and struvite crystal size in solution and when surface-bound, and that a microbial platform could serve as a scalable system for increasing struvite recovery from wastewater. Other peptide systems were also identified for phosphate recovery, and functional materials developed. As a result, other fields such as those focusing on separations and water treatment have new biomolecular tools in their repertoire.

Second a prospective life cycle assessment and economic analysis shed light on important potential hotspots in struvite recovery technology  performance in a simulated real-world environment prior to its integration into a pilot plant. Results show electrochemical struvite recovery and hydrogen capture appear to offer some benefits in the form of environmental credits and revenues generated through the sale of captured outputs. Environmental benefits include reductions in freshwater eutrophication and terrestrial acidification. Economic benefits include revenue generated from struvite and hydrogen gas. However, under current operating conditions, costs outweigh these benefits, with magnesium inputs being the largest limiting factor in both environmental and economic feasibility of the process. Future research and development of this technology should focus on this input to increase economic feasibility in addition to designing for the environment.

Third, additional agronomic and economic studies have shown that struvite generated in waste water treatment systems may be an agronomically (and sometimes economically) viable  phosphorus fertilizer source for row crop agriculture.  The nitrogen contained in struvite can off-set some of the additional nitrogen fertilizer that may be needed to supply crop-N needs for optimal growth and productivity. Numerous laboratory, greenhouse, and field studies were conducted to evaluate the behavior chemically and electrochemically precipitated struvite, produced from a synthetic wastewater in soil without plants and under moist- and flooded-soil conditions and agronomic response of struvite in flood-irrigated rice and furrow-irrigated corn, soybean, and wheat relative to other commonly used, commercially available fertilizer-P sources (i.e., rock phosphate, monoammonium phosphate, diammonium phosphate, and triple superphosphate). Study results showed that, based on more than 20 measured soil properties, chemically and electrochemically precipitated struvite generally behaved similar in soil without plants and under moist- and flooded-soil conditions to other commonly used, commercially available fertilizer-P sources. Overall, based on numerous replicated laboratory, greenhouse, and field studies with P-deficient soils and across multiple crops, chemically and electrochemically precipitated struvite appears to be a viable, alternative fertilizer-P source to various commonly used, commercially available fertilizer-P sources. However economic returns to struvite were mixed in the field studies.  This suggests a future need to comprehensively evaluate agronomic response of struvite made from an actual wastewater and further identify how electrochemically precipitated struvite can be a cost-effective material.

Fourth, the LCA work has been used to support the development of a novel perspective in the assessment of eutrophication impacts from point sources. Specifically, we now have tools to estimate the relative contribution from multiple upstream emission sources from a downstream location.

Finally the broader impact of this work includes supporting a pilot of a unique biomolecular engineering service learning initiative, which set the stage for future expansion. Outcomes of the service learning initiative included higher student self-efficacy in learning and doing science at the high school level and performing engineering design at the undergraduate and graduate and levels. In addition, the social responsibility attitudes of undergraduates and graduates increased. Conference presentations and a regional workshop in Arkansas connected researchers from the team to a broad stakeholder audience, including wastewater treatment utilities, private industry, and other researchers. An international collaboration between the team and NTNU in Norway allowed the team to expand its expertise with additional publications and researcher travel.
